If the Tariff is required to protect Australian industries against the cheap labour productions of Great Britain and foreign countries, how can such a statement be reconciled with the assertion that under it prices will not be increased? If prices are not to be increased as the result of this Tariff, then the proposed protection must fail. If locally-produced goods are to be sold as cheaply as imported goods, then there is nothing to fear from foreign competition, and there is no reason for the Tariff. But do .we not know, in the light of Victoria's long experience of protection, that the inevitable result of that policy is to increase to the consumer , the price of goods coming under it. It is ali very well to say, " We shall regulate prices by the appointment of an Inter-State Commission or a Board of Trade." But if we are going to regulate and bring down the prices of local articles to those of the imported article, a protective Tariff must be absolutely useless.
- I did not say that we should do such a thing.

- The honorable member, and others who share his view of. the fiscal question, have said again and again that the internal competition resulting from a high protective Tariff will effectively prevent the raising of prices to the consumer.
- What I say is that the increased output would enable local manufacturers to carry on with a smaller margin of profit.

- That necessarily means that they must sell at a reduced price. The argument of the protectionist anxious to throw dust in the eyes of traders invariably is that protection will not raise prices. A moment's consideration must show any reasonable man that protection would be absolutely useless unless it did. That is the purpose and object of a protective policy. Therefore, when protectionists profess to be indignant at the suggestion that prices have beenrasied because of protective duties, I very much doubt the sincerity of their protestations, or else am forced to the conclusion that they are unreasoning beings. When we are told of the advantages which have followed the removal, consequent upon Federation, of Tariff restrictions as between the States, we are naturally tempted to inquire whether a far more beneficial result would not attend the removal of the barriers to trade between Australia and other countries. If the principle is right in itself it must be right all along the line. If it is right that Australia as a whole should be a self-contained community, that it should manufacture everything that it requires for itself, and try to shut out the products of other countries, then we must contract the sphere of. operations, and apply the same principle to any division of Australia. . If it is right and . beneficial for the whole of Australia, it must be right and beneficial for any one State in the Commonwealth. Then again, if it be beneficial to any one State, it must be beneficial to any one country,, village, or household in Australia. When we come down to this - the -logical conclusion to the argument of the Protectionist Party - we find that we are reduced to the condition of primitive savages who have to manufacture everything for their own use, and have no opportunity or inclination to trade with others. We reach a condition of absolute barbarism.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - Where the people clothe themselves with, fig leaves.

- That proposition was hailed with satisfaction by one of the shining lights in the victorian world of protection; I refer to Mr. Joshua', who said, I believe, that he would prefer to see every one in Australia, clothed with the primitive fig leaf, rather than that they should wear any article not made in the Commonwealth. What a narrow provincial feeling such a statement displays ! A man who has expressed such a view needs to travel and learn something.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - Is Mr. Joshua a manufacturer of whisky?

- I believe he is. He now describes himself as the " top dog," and boasts of the power he possesses under the Tariff to take advantage of the unfortunate public. The consumers of any of the goods, dealt with in the Tariff are the last to be considered. What does it matter to him and those who share his view if the wife of a working man finds when she pays her grocer's bill at the end of the week that her husband's wages will not go as far as they did before this Tariff was imposed? What does it matter if she finds she has to pay more for her children's clothing? What does if matter if she cannot afford to buy boots for her boys and girls? She may not have the money, but she should rejoice to know that though her children go naked and hungry, the food and clothing as well as the money are all still in the country. Throughout Australia there is an outcry against the Tariff. But for the fact that as freetraders we have a duty to perform in seeking to reduce these duties to normal proportions, it would be well for us to allow the Tariff to pass as introduced.

speech.para: Mr.Mathews__ I wish the Opposition would give us the chance of passing it in that form.

talk.start.para: - I am pledged to fight for a reduction of the duties, and intend to do so. But for such a pledge I should say that the best thing that could happen to the cause of freedom and rationalism in this country would be the passing of the Tariff in its present form. If we let the people feel the pinch of it we should not have again to. appeal to them, as we have had to do, togo to the poll at a general election. The merchants, and, unfortunately, a good many of the women who have to make their husbands wages go as far as possible, as' well as women in other spheres of life who would feel the pinch of this Tariff, cannot be persuaded to go to the poll.
- The honorable member's crowd would not let them.
- Many of them did not do so at the last general election, but

speech.para: IfeelconfidentthatifthisTariff were to be passed as it stands the pinch would be felt by these people ; so keenly that at the next general election we should have such a revulsion of feeling, against protection that we might look forward to an era of free-trade placidity and real prosperity. We should not hear very much about protection for at least another decade.
Mr.Austin Chapman.- Can the honorable member tell us . if the workers, would secure any wages under the policy of which he is in favour?

talk.start.para: - I will undertake to say . that employment would be more plentiful and wages more satisfactory. The seasons of late have been so prosperous that had Parliament imposed no artificial barriers against commercial development, the people would be better off than they are now. When the leader of the Opposition was in power in . New South Wales, and ; the import duties affected only, . half-a-dozen items, and were . merely revenue producing - in their ' incidence, wages were . higher and industrial conditions better than in any other period in the history of the State. Unfortunately the Labour Party, in a -moment . of . madness, turned that Administration out- of office because of a paltry detail,andput into power : a. protectionist Government, which forthwith launched into the greatest extravagance, and increased the public debt by £15,000,000 before it could be got rid of.
- The honorable member admits that the Labour Party kept the right honorable member for East Sydney in power for. five years.

-It suited the Labour Party, to support him, because they got more democratic legislation from him than they had ever had before. He was the only man occupying a responsible position in politics who had the courage to face the big landholders, and propose a tax on land values, the -results of which were very beneficial, and' would have been more so had it not been for the exemptions insisted on by the leader of the Labour Party.
-bytherighthonorable member forEastSydney.
- I have the honorable member's speech.
- I remember the Bill.

- Western Australia, South Australia, Tasmania, and Queens land will suffer severely under the new Tariff, and the cost of mining operations-' at Broken Hill will be increased by something like , £40,000.
